results.firPara: Slaven Bilic believes that the atmosphere at the London Stadium will improve if West Ham United put a winning run together at their new home.
results.secPara: Although West Hams manager denied that it is a relief to be travelling to Crystal Palace on Saturday, he conceded that it is his responsibility to lift the mood by coaxing improved performances out of players who have looked ill at ease in home matches.
results.webTitle: West Ham have to win a few more games to feel at home, says Slaven Bilic

results.firPara: Ronald Koeman has issued a scathing attack on Martin ONeills treatment of James McCarthy and accused the Republic of Ireland of killing the Everton midfielder.
results.secPara: The Everton manager is incensed that McCarthy played the entirety of Irelands World Cup qualifying win against Georgia plus 81 minutes against Moldova in his first competitive outings since undergoing groin surgery last month. The player was sidelined for almost six weeks after the operation, and last played for Everton on 23 August, but started two World Cup qualifiers in four days having declared himself available for his country.
results.webTitle: Ronald Koeman laments Republic of Ireland duty ‘killing’ James McCarthy

results.firPara: Arsène Wenger has offered a vote of confidence to Olivier Giroud as the Arsenal striker contends with his false start to the season, in which he has been restricted to just 78 minutes of football for his club.
results.secPara: The manager reported that Girouds toe injury, which he sustained at Paris Saint‑Germain on 13 September and aggravated against Chelsea 11 days later, would keep the player out for a further two weeks, and it is plain that it is a frustrating time for the 30-year-old.
results.webTitle: Olivier Giroud backed by Arsène Wenger at Arsenal: ‘I can rely on him’

results.firPara: High fences, security cameras, razor wire and gatehouse vehicle checks modern Premier League training grounds often seem more like military installations than offshoots of the entertainment industry. If some of the protection and privacy is necessary, many clubs embrace effective lockdown mode a little too enthusiastically and David Moyes is suitably concerned about the resultant disconnect between players, supporters and reporters.
results.secPara: It explains why, this week, Sunderlands manager threw open the doors of his clubs magnificently appointed, if slightly windy, training HQ and offered journalists rare access all areas. Managers in charge of struggling clubs – and Sunderland are bottom of the table, with no Premier League wins and only two points this season – traditionally adopt siege mentalities but defying convention, Moyes allowed his guests to watch an entire training session as he prepared for Saturdays fixture at Stoke City.
results.webTitle: David Moyes opts for open-house approach as Sunderland seek first win

results.firPara: Liverpool have placed a salary cap on their academy players in an attempt to curb the excesses that can derail promising young careers.
results.secPara: Under the new policy, implemented with the support of the manager, Jürgen Klopp, 17‑year‑old players in the first season of a professional contract will not earn more than a basic salary of £40,000 a year. Tottenham Hotspur and Southampton have imposed similar limits on their academy players and Liverpool hope the move will ensure graduates remain focused on their career path to Klopps first team and are not distracted by the trappings of the job.
results.webTitle: Liverpool introduce £40,000-a-year salary cap for academy players

results.firPara: Leicester City lost only one of their main men in the summer but the French midfielder, who faces his former club at Stamford Bridge on Saturday, has been missed
results.secPara: In mid-August, when it became clear that Riyad Mahrez was following in Jamie Vardys footsteps and staying at Leicester City, Claudio Ranieri was asked how many players he imagined he would lose in the wake of winning the Premier League title. If I am honest, no one, the manager said, frowning. I thought everybody wanted to stay with Leicester and continue to fight. I made a mistake. One did want to go.
results.webTitle: Leicester’s loss of N’Golo Kanté is indisputably Chelsea’s gain

results.firPara: The Fifa president, Gianni Infantino, has defended his derided World Cup expansion plan and backed the idea of more than one country co-hosting the tournament in order to keep costs down.
results.secPara: Following the first meeting of the newly rebranded and expanded Fifa Council, which replaced the discredited executive committee, Infantino unveiled a vision document named Fifa 2.0 and a slew of targets and plans.
results.webTitle: Gianni Infantino unveils plans to increase World Cup to 40 or 48 teams

results.firPara: Gordon Strachan will continue as Scotland manager for the World Cup qualifier against England at Wembley next month after talks on Thursday with the Scottish Football Association.
results.secPara: Strachans future had been in doubt after a 3-0 defeat in Slovakia on Tuesday followed a 1-1 draw at home against Lithuania in Group F. However, the discussions established that there was no appetite on either side to end the former Celtic managers tenure at this stage.
results.webTitle: Gordon Strachan to remain in charge of Scotland against England in November

results.firPara: Mike Phelans long awaited confirmation as Hull Citys manager has finally been made official but he faces an immediate fight to rebuild the clubs backroom team after failing to prevent Aston Villa from poaching Stephen Clemence, his former assistant.
results.secPara: A key figure at the club, Clemence has rejoined his mentor, Steve Bruce, at Villa Park but fears that Gary Walsh, Hulls goalkeeping coach, may also be set to defect were allayed after Walsh made it clear that he has no desire to depart. Phelan – who assisted Bruce on Humberside before succeeding him on a caretaker basis – had hoped that a new-found sense of stability might have persuaded Clemence to stay but Villas pull ultimately proved too strong.
results.webTitle: Mike Phelan finally appointed as Hull’s permanent manager

results.firPara: In todays Fiver Bernard Cribbins MkII, Bill Kenwrights spirit level, and more
results.secPara: In todays Fiver Bernard Cribbins MkII, Bill Kenwrights spirit level, and more
